_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Safety specification titled Emergency Response and Planning, has been written and addresses such issues as; creation of an Emergency Response Team and the organizational structure, team membership criteria and responsibility, action guideline in the event of an incident, control of the hazard area, medical action plan, fire extinguisher training, decontamination plan, and SCBA respirator plan.   
 
Five Year Accident History
GlobiTech has had no accidental releases of any regulated chemicals in the past five years.  

Summary
	The partnership of GlobiTech and Air Products and Chemicals consists of significant knowledge and experience from both companies.  A checks and balance system between the two companies insures the safest approach to chemical handling and processing is followed, maintained, and reviewed on an ongoing basis.  The purity levels needed for an epitaxial deposition process demand the absolute highest quality materials, workmanship, and procedures.  This fact was known long before the initial design and was followed all the way through to commissioning the facility.  It continues with preventative maintenance knowing if the integrity of the system is compromised or breeched in any manner it is not only a safety concern but has damaging effect on business which cannot be tolerated.  
Another important step taken in regards to insuring safety was the hiring of an outside firm to conduct the Process Hazard Analysis for the TCS and HCl distribution system prior to construction completion.

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
GLOBITECH INC.
SHERMAN TEXAS
AUG 2008


Facility Description
	GlobiTech Incorporated is a 120,000-square-foot semiconductor facility located in Sherman Texas.  Sherman is located 60 miles north of Dallas Texas in Grayson County.  Construction began in February 2000 and the plant was occupied in July 2001.  The facility consists of a two level administration area located between two wafer fabs.  The wafer fabs are three level construction.  The first level contains the chemical delivery systems and related support equipment for the process tools such as power supplies and controllers.  The middle level of the wafer fab is an 8000-square-foot Class 1 cleanroom environment containing the manufacturing process equipment. The third level houses the air handling equipment for the cleanroom.  Behind the administrative area on the first level are more support equipment such as chillers, a boiler, and equipment used to make de-ionized water and a Control Center for the utilities.  Behind the administrative area on the second level is the main frame computer room and wafer stock room.  Located outside are storage tanks for the deionization water process, an Acid Waste Neutralization system, a cryogenic hydrogen storage tank and an ASU (air separation unit) for producing nitrogen.  Also located outside are the bulk supply and distribution systems for anhydrous hydrogen chloride (HCl) and trichlorosilane (TCS).  Both of these chemicals are received from the supplier in quantities above the threshold limits specified in OSHA¿s PSM program and the EPA¿s RMP program.   Epitaxial silicon wafers are produced at this facility.  

Process Description
	A thin (2-80 micron) single crystal layer of silicon is deposited on a silicon wafer.  The layer provides an ultra pure starting substrate for use by integrated device manufacturers to build integrated circuits commonly referred to as chips.  Trichlorosilane (SiHCl3) is the silicon source for the deposition.  The deposi

tion process takes place in an epi reactor at elevated temperatures high enough to separate the silicon atoms from the chlorine atoms contained in trichlorosilane.  The remaining hydrogen and chlorine atoms combine into hydrogen chloride.  This is the major byproduct of the deposition process and since it is hazardous must be scrubbed (treated) to state mandated levels before emission into the atmosphere.  Hydrogen chloride is also used to remove silicon that has deposited on equipment piece parts during the reaction.  An air permit from the state regulatory body, Texas Commission on Environmental Quality (TCEQ), was obtained prior to construction of the facility.  GlobiTech is labeled a ¿minor source¿ in regard to emissions due to the very small amount of HCl emitted after scrubbing.   Other processes associated with the deposition are wet cleaning of the wafers and parameter measurement such as electrical resistivity and thickness. 

Regulated Substances Handled
Anhydrous hydrogen chloride and trichlorosilane are the regulated chemicals handled on this site.  Hydrogen chloride and trichlorosilane are in quantities above threshold limits stated OSHA¿s PSM and the EPA¿s RMP programs therefore all required elements of each program are implemented. 

Worst Case Disaster Scenario 
	Worst-case disaster scenarios for both hydrogen chloride and trichlorosilane have been performed. An independent environmental consulting firm with extensive expertise in dispersion modeling performed the analysis using EPA recognized model DEGADIS.  In addition, EPA approved software RMP Comp was used internally and the results compared.  The DEGADIS dispersion model is much more involved and sophisticated and therefore more accurate.   These techniques are consistent with the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality and The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency procedures. They are based on the U.S. EPA RMP Guidance for Offsite Consequence Analysis, which defines the worst-case scenario as

the release of the largest quantity of a regulated substance from a single vessel or process line failure that results in the greatest distance to an endpoint that serious injury from short-term exposure will no longer occur.  
Hydrogen chloride (HCl) is received in anhydrous form via tube trailer truck.  The HCl is contained in seven separate pressurize tubes with each tube containing 3000lbs.  Trichlorosilane (TCS) is received in a 3800 gallon (43000 lbs) ISO container.  TCS reacts with the moisture in the air to form HCl.  The IDLH (Immediately Dangerous to Life and Health) value for HCl is 50ppm. Using the parameters listed in the table below, the toxic endpoint for the rupture of one of the tubes was calculated as well as rupture of the TCS container.



Parameter	Value
Release duration (min)	10
Stability class	F
Wind speed (m/s)	1.5
Anemometer height (m)	10
Ambient temp (oF)	109
Relative humidity (%)	65
Surface roughness (m)	0.3
Receptor height (m)	0
  
The distance to the endpoint for HCl based on the parameters above is 2.7 miles (4.3 kilometers) using RMP Comp and 1 mile (1.6 kilometers) according to DEGADIS.  Recall analysis using DEGADIS is a more detailed and accurate.  For HCl due to TCS release the end point according to DEGADIS is 0.7 miles (1200 meters).    
Besides Trichlorosilane (TCS) converting to HCl in the atmosphere it is also a flammable. Therefore a worst case flammable release scenario was performed using RMP Comp and the TNT Equivalent Model described in the EPA¿s RMP Guidance.  The estimated distance to an overpressure of 1 psi was determined to be 160 and 196 meters respectively, which is in the confines of the GlobiTech facility.  An alternative flammable release scenario using a pool fire instead of a vapor cloud explosion was preformed and also shows the release to be within the confines of the facility. 

Accident Prevention Program
	An Environmental Health and Safety specification titled Accident Prevention has been written and com

municated to all employees.  It addresses the following issues; creation of a Safety Committee and its responsibilities, accident investigation procedures, outlines authority, training, inspections, and audits. Other written specifications include; Lock out/Tag out, Haz Com, Confined Space, Contractor Safety, Emergency Eyewash and Showers, Emergency Egress, Chemical Safety and Storage, Hazardous Work permits, Hot Work Permit, Toxic Gas Monitoring, Chemical Spill and Release Response Procedures, Hazardous Waste Management, Blood Borne Pathogens, Reporting and Recording Injuries and Illnesses, Slug Control, and all fourteen elements outlined in OSHA¿ PSM.  Both TCS and HCl bulk delivery systems are equipped with leak detection sensors connected to a site wide Toxic Gas Monitoring (TGM) system with shutdown capabilities. In addition to the TGM, restrictive flow orifices and excess flow detection, low-low and high-high detection systems are in place with shutdown capabilities. The TCS bulk delivery area is further equipped with an AFFF foam suppression system and 110% secondary containment.  Any loss of exhaust detected at any gas cabinet or the process tool (reactor) a shutdown of the source gas will occur.  Barricades (bollards) are in place for both TCS and HCl at the outdoor gas pad.   
	Air Products and Chemicals Incorporated (APCI) is an embedded contractor at GlobiTech.   A written agreement exists between APCI and GlobiTech stating ownership of equipment as well as ownership of the chemical.  With this type of agreement both GlobiTech and APCI employees are involved in all chemical supply change outs and associated work.  This insures procedures developed by GlobiTech and those developed by APCI are reviewed by both parties and a ¿best possible¿ procedure is used.
